definitions.definition: a small piece of paper with a design on it that you buy and stick on an envelope or a package before you post it

examples.text: a 67p stamp
Could I have three first-class stamps, please?
He has been collecting stamps since he was eight.
a stamp album
The Post Office has issued a commemorative stamp to mark the event.
Don't forget to put a stamp on.
She stuck a first-class stamp on the letter.
The Post Office has launched some new Christmas stamps.
The stamps were issued in 1863.
a book of ten first-class stamps

definitions.definition: a tool for printing the date or a design or mark onto a surface

examples.text: a date stamp

definitions.definition: a design or words made by stamping something onto a surface

examples.text: The passports, with the visa stamps, were waiting at the embassy.
The project has the government's **stamp of approval**.

definitions.definition: a small piece of paper with a design on it, stuck on a document to show that a particular amount of money has been paid

examples.text: a TV licence stamp

definitions.definition: the mark or sign of a particular quality or person

examples.text: All his work **bears the stamp** of authority.
President Reagan left an indelible stamp on the nation.
She left her stamp on the school.
His work bears the unmistakable stamp of genius.
He has a new chance to put his stamp on policy.

definitions.definition: a kind or class, especially of people

examples.text: men of a different stamp

definitions.definition: an act or sound of stamping the foot

examples.text: The stamp of hoofs alerted Isabel.

wordOrigin: Middle English (in the sense ‘crush to a powder’): of Germanic origin; related to German stampfen ‘stamp with the foot’; reinforced by Old French estamper ‘to stamp’. Compare with stomp.
